page.title: 03Agriculture - Livestock.
page.content: Cattle graze the fields in summer, controlled by electric fences. In winter they are housed in indoor cubicles and are fed silage, grass and maize, supplemented with fodder beet and concentrates. The dairy cows are Friesians; some bred pure for replacements, others bred to Hereford Charolais, Limousin, Simmental or Belgian Blue to produce calves for beef. Most of the beef calves are sold. Milk quotas introduced in 1984 are used to control output and have resulted in fewer cows being kept and less purchased concentrates being fed. Sheep live in the fields all year round, except for a few days at lambing time. Goat-keeping is increasing in popularity. A few riding horses are kept for pleasure and racing.
